documentType: Bureau of Prisons internal memorandum and psychological reconstruction report
summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons psychological reconstruction report on the suicide of inmate Jeffrey Epstein on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. The report details his background, legal history, mental health assessments, and the circumstances leading to his death, including a prior incident on July 23, 2019. It concludes with operational recommendations for suicide prevention. This document is a portion of an internal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) report reviewing the circumstances surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It details numerous procedural failures, documentation inaccuracies, and lapses in protocol related to suicide prevention, inmate monitoring, and record-keeping.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York at approximately 6:33 a.m. and was pronounced dead at 7:36 a.m. The report concludes his death was a suicide.

events.title: Prior Incident/Suspected Suicide Attempt
events.description: Epstein was found in his cell with a piece of orange cloth around his neck, lying in the fetal position. He was placed on suicide watch. He denied it was a suicide attempt and initially claimed his cellmate tried to kill him.

events.title: Arrest of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Epstein was arrested at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey upon his return from Paris, France, and transported to MCC New York.

events.title: Bail Denial
events.description: Judge Richard M. Berman denied Jeffrey Epstein's request for bail and pretrial release, remanding him to custody.

events.title: Court Documents Unsealed
events.description: Approximately 2,000 pages of court documents were unsealed, containing graphic allegations against Epstein and naming other high-profile figures, including Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Epstein Found Unresponsive in Cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at MCC New York with abrasions on his neck and knee. Inconsistent documentation described the scene (e.g., 'string' vs. 'piece of handmade orange cloth' around his neck).

events.title: Epstein on Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein was placed on suicide watch after being found unresponsive. During this period, procedural failures occurred, including the use of the wrong log book and lack of direct, continuous observation during attorney visits.

events.title: Epstein's Arrival at MCC New York
events.description: Epstein arrived at MCC New York. A Facility Assistant observed him as 'distraught, sad and a little confused' and emailed staff recommending a psychologist speak with him, but required follow-up did not occur.

events.title: Epstein Denied Bail
events.description: A judge denied Epstein bail, which the report notes was a 'significant disappointment' that likely challenged his ability to adapt to incarceration. No psychologist assessed him upon his return to the institution.

events.title: Unmonitored Phone Call
events.description: Epstein was escorted to the SHU to place an unmonitored telephone call. He claimed to be calling his deceased mother. The call was placed using a number beginning with area code 347.

events.title: Inconclusive SIS Threat Assessment
events.description: A Special Investigative Services (SIS) Threat Assessment was completed but was inconclusive as to whether Epstein's injuries were from self-directed violence, a fight with his cellmate, or an assault by his cellmate.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide on August 10, 2019, while in pretrial custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York.
The reconstruction was severely limited because the FBI had confiscated the original video footage and formal interviews were not conducted to avoid interfering with other DOJ investigations.
On July 23, 2019, Epstein was found with a cloth around his neck in an incident staff could not definitively classify as an assault or a suicide attempt; he was placed on suicide watch for 31 hours.
On the night of his death, Epstein was single-celled because his cellmate did not return from court, and staff failed to assign him a new cellmate despite communication about the need.
Correctional officers Tova Noel and Michael Thomas admitted they did not complete the required 30-minute rounds at 3:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. on the morning Epstein died.
Significant inconsistencies exist in the documentation of the scene where Epstein was found unresponsive on July 23, 2019, with different descriptions of the object around his neck.

Critical failures in suicide watch protocol occurred, including a correctional officer using the wrong log book and another staff member falsifying entries by copying and initialing them, obscuring who was actually monitoring Epstein.

Epstein received extensive, unmonitored attorney visits (often over 10 hours per day) while on psychological observation, during which required 'direct, continuous observation' by BOP staff was not maintained.
Epstein was allowed to make an unmonitored telephone call on August 9, 2019, where he claimed to be calling his deceased mother, highlighting a breakdown in controlled communication procedures.

The report identifies systemic issues with record-keeping at MCC NY, including inaccurate inmate cell assignments in the SENTRY system, unsecured attorney log books after Epstein's death, and numerous incomplete or erroneous official forms.
